_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies
In this distribution facility we handle chlorine, which is considered hazardous by EPA.  The same properties that make chlorine valuable as a commodity also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling chlorine to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to our own personal health as well as that of our co-workers, and to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community.  Vertex has implemented and maintains the elements of the Vertex Risk Management Program for all operating facilities.  Vertex senior management leadership implements through policy, participation, communications and resource commitments in achieving continuous improvement of performance to control risks of any sort to the community that could be controlled by Vertex.  Additionally, it is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and State rules and regulations.  Vertex is committed to a secure and safe environment, which depends upon the manner in which we handle chlorine, the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, the safe handling procedures that we use, and the training of our personnel.

Vertex emergency response program is based upon the Chlorine Institute?s Pamphlet 64, ?Emergency Response Plans for Chlorine Facilities?, the American Chemistry Council?s Responsible Care(R) Management Systems, and applicable regulations.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.

2.  Vertex facility and regulated substances handled
The primary purpose of this facility is to manufacture sodium hypochlorite for bi-state area customers.  Sodium hypochlorite bleaches for household, commercial and industrial uses are the sole products made by Vertex.  This site is remote from neighbors and protected with natural obstacles.  Access to the site is restricted to au

thorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.  The regulated substance handled at this facility is chlorine, although no chlorine is shipped out of the facility.  Inventory is maintained at lowest amounts practical to insure continued supply to the water purification and commercial needs of customers.

3.  The general accidental release prevention program and the specific prevention steps
This distribution facility complies with EPA?s Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  Although not subject to OSHA PSM at this time, nonetheless Vertex is in compliance with this rule.  This facility is operated in accordance with recommendations from the Chlorine Institute and is an American Chemistry Council Responsible Care(R) participant.  Many redundant safety and security systems are in place, and every employee involved in Vertex bleach manufacture is trained to Incident Command level in case of an emergency.

4.  Five-year accident history
Vertex Chemical Corporation has three facilities which manufacture sodium hypochlorite using chlorine.  None of these facilities has experienced a reportable spill of chlorine nor any off-site consequences.

5.  The Emergency Response Program
Procedures have been developed over the fifty-year history of Vertex in bleach manufacture to minimize the possibility of accidental chlorine release.  Multiple safety and security measures have also been implemented/installed.  Vertex emergency response is coordinated with Camanche Fire Department, the Davenport Fire Department Hazmat Division and the Clinton County Emergency Management.  Vertex personnel receive annual training, participate in regular safety and security meetings and multiple drills and exercises annually.  This facility?s emergency response program is based upon the Chlorine Institute?s Pamphlet 64, Emergency Response Plans for Chlorine Facilities.  We have hosted meetings at our facility

annually, to which the Local Emergency Planning Committee Chairman, Police and Fire Departments have been invited/attended for Haz Mat education/tour.  Vertex programs have been discussed.  Representatives of the Camanche Fire Department, the Davenport Fire Department Hazmat Division and the Clinton County Sheriff?s Department visited the facility November 17, 2003.  This was the second cooperative drill in 2003.

6.  Planned changes to improve safety
This facility was constructed in 1985, with the most recent upgrade in 2003.  It is in compliance with Chlorine Institute guidelines.  We continue to participate in the Chlorine Institute programs, and continue to improve our operations in accordance with Responsible Care(R) Management System guidelines and all applicable regulations.
